Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES Planning Grant: Broadening Participation of Underserved Students in STEM and CTE in the Middle Grades

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration: This NSF INCLUDES planning grant is funded by NSF Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science (NSF INCLUDES), a comprehensive national initiative to enhance U.S. leadership in discoveries and innovations by focusing on diversity, inclusion and broadening participation in STEM at scale. The NAPE Education Foundation will build on the success of its NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilot, Intermountain (IM) STEM, to plan for and develop a national alliance of local and state change agents--leaders from organizations with influence over policies, practices and resource flows--using a collective impact framework. The goal of this national alliance is to increase the participation, retention, and program completion in STEM and career and technical education (CTE) pathways of girls; individuals who are Black, Indigenous or Native, and People of Color; and individuals from the broadened definition of special populations in Perkins V, with a particular focus on students with disabilities and students from economically disadvantaged families. The recently reauthorized Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act (Perkins V), now aligned with the Every Student Succeeds Act, contains new provisions emphasizing the need for CTE experiences and career guidance and counseling in the middle grades (5-8 grades), which is a critical time for studentsâ€™ STEM course-taking decisions. Using this critical juncture in the education pathway, NAPE and the co-PIs from the California Department of Education, the South Carolina Department of Education, the Utah STEM Action Center, Butler Tech Schools in Ohio, and other partners will create a national collective impact network to build capacity for diversity in CTE in the middle grades.<br/><br/>This planning grant represents a national public and private partnership of large well-positioned organizations brought together to collaborate on addressing the broadening participation challenges in STEM and CTE. The project will advance the knowledge of how collaborative efforts can lead to transformative systems change. The planning process will focus on three design elements of collaborative infrastructure: creating a shared vision; building partnerships; and identifying goals and metrics to measure progress and outcomes. The process will also include an external evaluator who will conduct a formative evaluation and whose expertise will be used in setting goals and metrics. The planning process will include leadership development, partnership expansion, crowdsourcing, and virtual convenings resulting in a strategic plan for a national collective impact network to address equity gaps in STEM and CTE. This effort will bring the STEM and CTE community together to plan the formation of a collective impact alliance that will foster an ecosystem with the capacity to inform and empower educational stakeholders to create the needed systems change that will ensure the participation of underrepresented students in STEM and CTE.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Alliance for Partnerships in Equity Education Foundation (NAPE) brought together 48 partners representing 25 states in a national collective impact alliance-Workforce and Education Alliance to Realize Equity in STEM and CTE in the Middle Grades (WE ARE STEM & CTE)-focused on broadening access and opportunity for underrepresented students, including female, underrepresented students of color, and students from special populations, in STEM education and Career and Technical Education (CTE). The goal of the planning grant was to develop a strategic plan for a national Alliance of cross-sector partners dedicated to broadening participation in CTE and STEM for underrepresented students in the middle grades (5-10). Alliance partners included local education agencies, state education agencies, postsecondary institutions, and local, state, and national STEM and CTE organizations committed to systems change and a shared vision to close equity and opportunity gaps in STEM and CTE education for students in grades 5-10. The project included six key activities:

1. Leadership Development: The project used a tiered leadership structure to manage project activities and partner input. Steering Committee, Workgroup Chairs, and members took turns leading meetings to build the capacity of the network and partners to utilize collective impact as model for Alliance development. Additionally, the team used crowdsourcing in regional and national convenings to inform the development of a strategic plan for the Alliance.  

2. Partnership Expansion: The project conducted outreach to bring additional partners into the planning process at the leadership and network levels. Partner engagement included Steering Committee, Workgroup, and Partner meetings, partner surveys, three virtual national convenings, and presentations by Partners at School board meetings, state education agency briefings, and other state and local education activities. These activities also supported sharing of best practices across the national Alliance network.

3. Crowdsourcing: The Alliance held a series of Partner meetings and virtual convenings to solicit input from the wider STEM and CTE community on the shared vision and strategic plan for the Alliance. Partners provided input through Google jamboards and workgroup worksheets that solicited input specific to the goals and objectives of each workgroup. 


4. Virtual Network Convening Facilitation: The project team facilitated five planning meetings for Partners plus three network convenings to solicit input from a wider array of experts, utilizing Google jamboards, breakout groups, and virtual chats to gather input to help shape the Alliance. 


5. Synthesis: Utilizing the feedback from Partners and the network, the Management Team and Steering Committee developed a logic model, a problem/goal statement, and a shared vision for the Alliance, as well as a strategic plan to achieve this vision, implement the activities, and meet the outcomes identified in the logic model.


6. Resource Acquisition: The strategic plan identified partner assets and potential funders to support parts or all of the Alliance start-up and expansion, which will continue to guide future Alliance collaboration. The Alliance team developed and submitted a proposal in response to the NSF INCLUDES Alliances program in January 2022 to support the full launch of the Alliance. 


Intellectual Merit: The WE ARE STEM & CTE Alliance represents a national public and private partnership of diverse organizations brought together to collaborate on addressing broadening participation challenges in STEM and CTE, thereby advancing the knowledge of how creative social innovations, such as collective impact, can create transformative systems change. The Alliance is positioned to drive systems change by influencing education policy, practices, and resources that positively impact equity in STEM and CTE education pathways in the middle grades (5-10), which is a critical time for students' STEM course-taking decisions and when significant challenges for underrepresented students create barriers to their participation. Key outcomes included: (1) Increased collaboration between the Partners focused on equity in STEM and CTE; (2) Increased knowledge and use of systems change models to address equity in STEM and CTE; (3) Increased sharing of resources and personal knowledge of issues and strategies for impacting systems of oppression, gender equity and racial justice; and (4) Increased implementation by Partners of programs in STEM and CTE that are more inclusive and result in the closing of equity gaps in participation and achievement.


Broader Impacts:  The reauthorization of the Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act (Perkins V) that expanded CTE into the middle grades and the increased emphasis on closing equity gaps in CTE and STEM in federal and state education policy have created a significant opportunity for the STEM and CTE community to impact this trend. Organizing this community together in a collective impact alliance has the potential to create the needed systems change to broaden participation and shift STEM workforce outcomes. The Alliance will foster a STEM ecosystem with the capacity to inform and empower educational stakeholders to create needed systems change that will ensure the participation of underrepresented students in STEM and CTE.
